triples.evidence: In this sense, an alternating current circuit can be treated just like a direct current circuit - once we use phasor notation and impedance. That's why we say AC is DC in disguise.

concepts.term: differential equations into simple algebraic ones
AC circuit analysis can be so elegant

evidence: In this sense, an alternating current circuit can be treated just like a direct current circuit - once we use phasor notation and impedance. That's why we say AC is DC in disguise.
By representing AC voltages and currents as phasors, we turn differential equations into simple algebraic ones, just like in DC analysis.

This clever idea was first developed decades ago by an engineer at the GE Global Research Center, not far from here. It's now a standard computational tool in electrical engineering, and it's one of the reasons AC circuit analysis can be so elegant.

triples.evidence: In this sense, an alternating current circuit can be treated just like a direct current circuit - once we use phasor notation and impedance.
That's why we say AC is DC in disguise.
